title: First-time animal injury
vignette: A normally placid bull knocks over a neighbour’s cow, breaking its leg.

options.text: The bull’s owner pays only half the loss because the animal had no history of violence.
The owner pays the full cost; everyone must guard even a first-time incident.

title: Animal proven dangerous
vignette: After three prior attacks, a farmer’s bull gores again.

options.text: From now on the owner always pays full damages.
The owner still pays only half if he warned neighbours and kept the bull tied.

title: Pregnant cow struck
vignette: A runaway bull kills a cow and the calf it was carrying.

options.text: Pay only for the cow; the unborn calf has no separate value.
Compensate for both the cow and the calf because potential life has worth.

title: Injury to hired worker
vignette: A bull gores a household servant, killing him.

options.text: The owner pays a fixed compensation that ignores the servant’s actual market value.
The owner should pay the full real value, just as for any person.

title: Shallow hole in the road
vignette: Jon digs a shallow pit in the street; a donkey falls in and dies.

options.text: He pays only if the pit was at least a set depth.
Any hole he left is his responsibility, depth doesn’t matter.

title: Fire carried by strong wind
vignette: Lena’s backyard bonfire sends embers that a gust carries onto a neighbour’s wheat stack, burning it.

options.text: Lena is always liable; starting a fire is like shooting an arrow.
If the wind was unusually strong and unexpected, the loss is an accident.

title: Torch ignites shopfront
vignette: A porter walks through town with an open torch that sets a stall’s awning alight.

options.text: The porter is liable—he should have shielded the flame.
The stall owner shares the blame for using flammable material above a busy path.

title: Chain-reaction damage
vignette: A runaway bull tips a jar; the jar smashes a lantern; the lantern starts a fire that destroys goods.

options.text: Pay full losses for every link in the chain; the bull set it all in motion.
Liability ends with the first direct breakage.

title: Accidental personal injury
vignette: While texting, Dan bumps someone, who falls and breaks an arm.

options.text: Dan is liable even if it seemed accidental—people must watch where they walk.
True accidents are exempt if no negligence can be shown.

title: Compensation categories for assault
vignette: An attacker injures a victim’s leg, causing pain and lost work.

options.text: Pay five elements: damage, pain, medical bills, lost wages, and humiliation.
Owe only medical bills and lost wages; the rest are moral, not monetary.

title: Hitting a parent
vignette: Someone strikes his father, leaving a bruise.

options.text: Same payments as for hitting any stranger.
Extra penalty; striking a parent is especially serious.

title: False testimony penalty
vignette: Two people lie in court that Levi owes $1 000.

options.text: When exposed, they must pay Levi the full $1 000 they tried to extract.
They pay only court fines; Levi gets no personal compensation.

title: Theft multiplier
vignette: A thief steals a neighbour’s sheep and sells it.

options.text: Must pay four times the value (five if it were an ox).
Double payment is enough; bigger multiplier applies only if the animal was slaughtered.

title: Ignoring safety instructions
vignette: A borrower leads a cow across thin ice despite the owner’s warning; the cow slips and is hurt.

options.text: Borrower pays—he ignored explicit advice.
If the ice unexpectedly cracked, it is an unavoidable accident.

title: Robbery versus covert theft
vignette: An armed robber grabs a laptop openly in daylight.

options.text: Robber owes the item plus damages for public humiliation.
Same liability as a covert thief; the difference is only moral, not financial.

title: Stolen boards built into bench
vignette: Stolen planks are built into a public bench.

options.text: Must dismantle the bench and return the original planks.
Pay the lumber’s value instead; destroying the bench helps no one.

title: Unauthorized planting
vignette: A farmer secretly plants wheat on unused land owned by someone else.

options.text: Landowner keeps the crop but repays the farmer’s expenses.
Farmer keeps the crop but owes rent for using the land.

title: Benefit without owner’s loss
vignette: A tenant lives in an otherwise empty attic; the owner wants rent.

options.text: No rent—owner lost nothing.
Any benefit requires payment even if the owner’s loss isn’t measurable.

title: Dropped stone breaks window
vignette: A loose stone falls from someone’s pocket and cracks a shop window.

options.text: He is liable; personal items must be secured.
He is exempt if the fall was truly unforeseeable.

title: Hazard on shared property
vignette: Two partners share a courtyard; one digs a hole and the other’s goat falls in.

options.text: The digger is liable—he created the hazard without consent.
Both own the yard, so each assumed the risk.

title: Animal startled by bystander
vignette: A child claps loudly; a nearby ox bolts and gores a passer-by.

options.text: Owner is still liable; he must restrain the ox.
The bystander shares liability for provoking the ox.

title: Dog drags ember
vignette: A dog steals bread that has a glowing coal on it, setting a barn on fire.

options.text: Dog’s owner pays full; such fires are foreseeable.
Owner pays only half; the chain of events lessens liability.

title: Boards left in road
vignette: A work crew leaves planks on a street overnight; a cyclist hits them and crashes.

options.text: Crew is liable; they created a hazard.
The city also bears blame for not inspecting the street.

title: Unsecured ladder falls
vignette: A homeowner’s ladder tips over in high wind and injures a pedestrian.

options.text: Homeowner fully liable; improper placement.
Only partly liable; the strong wind was unforeseeable.

title: Tailor ruins fabric
vignette: A tailor accidentally cuts expensive silk off-pattern.

options.text: Tailor pays the market value for the ruined fabric.
Tailor returns the damaged silk; the customer absorbs part of the loss.

title: Guard falls asleep
vignette: A paid night guard dozes off and thieves steal a flock.

options.text: Guard pays in full—sleeping is negligence.
Guard is liable only if he was warned against sleeping.

title: Courier loses documents
vignette: A messenger misplaces an original signed deed while in transit.

options.text: Courier is liable; the document is irreplaceable.
Courier pays only proven monetary loss, not sentimental or delay damages.

title: Late wage payment
vignette: A farmhand finishes work at sunset but the owner pays the next morning.

options.text: This violates the agreement; wages are due the same evening.
A short delay is acceptable if the worker is still nearby.

title: Animal and uncovered pit
vignette: An ox pushes a goat into someone’s uncovered pit.

options.text: Ox owner and pit owner split the liability.
Only the pit owner pays; the pit caused the final harm.

title: Borrower leaves door unlatched
vignette: A borrower forgets to latch the door; thieves steal borrowed tools inside.

options.text: Borrower pays—the duty to guard is like the owner’s.
Pays only if theft was foreseeable in that area.

title: Animal eats in garden vs. street
vignette: A goat wanders into a neighbour’s garden and eats lettuce; later it nibbles scraps on the public sidewalk.

options.text: Owner pays full for garden damage but nothing for the street.
Owner pays for damage anywhere the goat eats; allowing it to roam is negligence.

title: Stones kicked by hooves
vignette: A cow’s hoof flicks pebbles through a shop window, cracking the glass.

options.text: Owner pays half; the damage is indirect.
Owner pays full; such consequences are foreseeable.

title: First-time gore on victim’s land
vignette: A normally tame bull gores once in its owner’s yard and next day gores in the neighbour’s yard.

options.text: Half-damage in either place; first-time attacks are always half.
Owner pays full when the goring happens on the neighbour’s property.

title: Weak cover over pit
vignette: Yehuda digs a pit in the street and covers it with a flimsy board; the board collapses and a donkey is hurt.

options.text: Pit-digger is liable; the cover was inadequate.
If the cover met normal standards, the collapse was unforeseeable and he is exempt.

title: Servant breaks item on errand
vignette: A domestic helper carrying groceries for her employer drops a shop’s vase.

options.text: Employer pays—the servant acts as his agent on the errand.
Servant pays personally for careless handling.

title: Child carries lit torch
vignette: A homeowner lets a child carry a lit torch home; a spark ignites a neighbour’s haystack.

options.text: Homeowner is liable; sending fire, even via a child, is his act.
Liability is reduced; the child’s unpredictable action breaks the chain.

title: Borrower lends to third party
vignette: Sara borrows a rake, then—without permission—lends it to Dina, who breaks it.

options.text: Sara pays; transferring without consent voids the terms.
Dina pays; she directly caused the damage.

title: Paying from best land
vignette: After losing a damages case, a debtor owns low-, medium-, and high-grade fields.

options.text: The creditor may seize the best field to ensure full value.
Take only a medium field; the finest land is reserved for fixed-amount debts like dowries.
